field_reports.description:
Although case numbers remain low, Ghana sits in a high-risk corridor: neighbouring Côte d’Ivoire, Sierra Leone, and DRC continue to report Clade I Mpox transmission, some with rising trends. The Africa CDC has extended the Mpox Public Health Emergency of Continental Security (PHECS) designation into May 2025, urging continued regional coordination and vaccine deployment for high-risk groups. At the national level, GHS, supported by GRCS, has scaled up point-of-entry screening, community-based surveillance, and risk communication campaigns, while stockpiling antivirals and planning for targeted vaccination of healthcare workers and contacts 

In mid-May 2025, Ghana confirmed its first two Mpox cases—one each in the Greater Accra and Western Regions—prompting the Ghana Health Service (GHS) to declare a fresh outbreak and begin enhanced surveillance and contact tracing. By May 18, total confirmed infections had risen to four cases linked to Clade Ib virus strains with potential household transmission. Regional health authorities immediately activated the Public Health Emergency Operations Centre (PHEOC), mobilised personal protective equipment (PPE), and disseminated national Mpox case definitions and testing protocols to all district health facilities.

Although confirmed cases have been detected in urban centres (Accra, Takoradi), rural and border communities are considered highly vulnerable due to limited healthcare access and high inter-community mobility. Demographically, Clade Ib Mpox has shown greater spread among adults (18–45 years) through intimate contact and within households, raising concerns for potential spill-over to children and immunocompromised individuals. Even with low case counts, fear and stigma have disrupted daily life. The Mpox preparedness and response has diverted resources from routine services, including immunisation and maternal health. Informal trade and market activities slowed due to reduced cross-border.

Ghana’s Mpox response since May 2025 has combined targeted epidemiological surveillance, community‐level risk communication, and cross‐sector coordination to contain the spread. While confirmed cases remain limited, ongoing vigilance, particularly in border and rural areas, is essential to prevent wider transmission and mitigate socioeconomic impacts.

results.summary:
In October 2024, the Ghana Health Service has announced a cholera outbreak affecting five regions in the country, notably: Greater Accra,
Central, Western, Eastern and Asanti. As part of the interventions strategies to reverse the spread of the disease, Ghana Health Service in
collaboration with UNICEF and partners in November 2024 introduced cholera vaccine- Oral cholera vaccine (OCV). The vaccine was rolled
out in 3 subdistricts of the Central region, which is the epicenter of the epidemic, and 662,906 out of 792,482 eligible population were
successfully vaccinated. Phase 2 subnational OCV campaign successfully completed in 18 subdistricts within 4 hotspot districts of Western
Region (Sekondi-Takoradi, Ea Kwesimintsim, Shama and Ahanta West) between 15 to 18 December 2024. A total of 596,205 persons
(92.9% of target population) were vaccinated. That said, the unvaccinated gap continues to pose a threat to since the vaccinate region is
still reporting pocket of cases, and other aected regions as well. The Ghana RC has been quite active during the initial phases and needs
more resources to continue playing its auxiliary role to the government in this response.

On December 19, 2024, the outbreak had claimed 27 lives and spread across 36 districts in the Greater Accra, Central, Western, and
Eastern regions, with a total of 3,292 reported cases. While the number of cases in the Western Region is declining mainly due to
the vaccination campaign, there is an increase in geographical spread and a rise in cases in the other regions. Between 24 and 31
December 2024, 29 new cases and 1 new death were recorded, with a cumulative number of 4,850 suspected cases from the begining of
the epidemic and 1 new affected district. These gures indicate that the epidemic continues to spread and there is a need to continue the
initial eorts to ensure an ecient response.
results.name: GHA: Epidemic - 01-2025 - Cholera Outbreak

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: The Ministry of Health (MoH) has announced a Dengue outbreak in the Eastern region of Ghana. Nine Cases were reported, and laboratory investigation confirmed the nine cases were dengue. An out has been issued to various regions and districts to engage the general public. A National Medical team has been deployed to join the affected region for further investigation. Surveillance systems have been activated at the community level for case detection for early action.

field_reports.description:
Highest impact in were reported with floods on 14.10.2023 In Volta region when the Akasombo dam experienced an increased water flows which forced the authorities to open the flood gates. This led to the flooding of communities in Central, North and South of Tongu districts, it is reported that over 26,857 people alone have been affected by the floods, at least seven people injured. The displaced people have been moved to higher grounds. Dozens of people have been isolated as the floods have affected the road network. One hospital had to be evacuated due to high water levels. The situation is set to worsen as the Ghana Met has forecasted increased rainfall in the areas.

On 23rd September 2023, torrential rains experienced in Savannah region, subsequently resulting in the black volta bursting its banks and flooding affecting about 5,000 people in six communities in Central Gonja district, leading to the destruction of houses, public infrastructure such as schools, and also the flooding of farmlands where a significant number of crops were lost. The flooding which has been gradually increasing in intensity due to the heavy rainfall have caused displacement of 540 families to evacuation centres in higher grounds. 

Other displaced families were hosted by families who live in high grounds and evacuation centres. In both regions, the displaced populations of 26,857 people have lost their properties, farm products and means of livelihoods. Successive impacts and continuation of rains is still putting the North in additional risk of flooding.

According to the local National Disaster Management Organisation(NADMO) the overflow of black volta as a result of spillage from Bui dam has caused extensive flood water damage to several homes at Buipe and other surrounding community in the Central Gonja district of Savannah Region. The majority of affected households have been evacuated to the jointly set-up evacuation center by Local Red Cross and National Disaster Management Organisation. The local branch of Ghana Red Cross Society is currently assessing how best to support the most vulnerable families affected by the disaster.

results.summary:
According to the Ghana Met (GMet) Agency forecast June to September 2023 issued on 5th May 2023, incidence of above normal rainfall are forecasted in the peak of rainy season (end August to early September) in Upper east region while the overall Northern part of the country ranking from normal to above normal is also likely to face mainly flash floods and revering floods incidence exacerbated by the annual opening of Bagre dam in Burkina Faso once it reach the 235m during the same period.

The National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) and the Meteorological Agency have issued a warming of increased rainfall and flooding and advised people who live in high risk flooding areas to move to higher grounds. It is forecasted that more regions in the northern part will experience flooding as a result of above normal rainfall. The historical impact analysis has shown that, over the past years, the floods impacted around 70,000 people (source: CIMA, UNIDSR, 2018, Ghana Disaster Risk Profile)

Ghana is affected by:
- Flash floods worst in urban areas due to urbanization challenges
- Revering flooding mainly linked to the important river systems length crossing from Others countries, especially Burkina Faso and going through all the North regions up to the South of Ghana. The most overflowing rivers are the White and black Volta and its tributaries like Oti River, which flows into Lake Volta from the northeast.

The connection of this river system with Burkina Faso is worsening the overall flooding situation in Ghana since the annual spilling of water from Bagre Dam in Burkina Faso make an overflowing of all the river system in Ghana, impacting first the Northern regions and areas around the rivers, beaches and dams in Northern region, Upper East, Savannah, Northeast, and Upper West. Bagre Dam is open annually when it reach 255 M which is the maximum level.

GRCS historical data analysis shows that authorities usually alert the NADMO (National Disaster Management Organization) in Ghana in charge of disseminating the information. In the past, Hydroelectric Production Department of SONABEL of Burkina Faso, open the Bagre Dam on 1st September 2022 when it reach 235M. In 2018 it was in 31 August. In general, over the years, the opening of Dam happen from 30 August to 3rd September. Others dam spilling can also be recorded but Bagre is the recurrent one.
results.name: GHA: 2023 Imminent floods

field_reports.description:
In several regions of Ghana, severe flooding has resulted in the loss of life, the devastation of homes, and the displacement of entire communities. Included in the affected regions are Greater Accra, Western, Ashanti, and Volta in the beginning June 2023. At least 6632 people have been affected, 7 dead and 3974 people displaced in four affected regions.

Ghana Red Cross Society Response, at Ho in the Volta Region, the Regional Branch Manager took part in the rapid assessment team together with the Regional Coordinating Council, National Disaster Management Organisation, and other state agencies to assess the Ho Municipality floods. The District Disaster Response Team (DDRTs) of Keta Municipal responded and assisted in evacuating the affected people to safe havens.

results.summary:
On 20th January 2022, a large blast occurred in an area at Apeate community, near the city of Bogoso about 300km (180 miles) west of the capital of Ghana, Accra. The explosion occurred when a motorcycle went under a truck carrying explosives that were en route to the gold mine at Bogoso. After the blasts, people in the community rushed down to the scene when a second blast occurred a few minutes later. This resulted in the destruction of dozens of buildings. 

As of 22nd January, a total of 17 people had been confirmed dead, and some 59 injured people were rescued and referred to Bogoso Government Hospital where they are receiving treatment. As of 26th January, 3,300 persons (1,122 males and 2,178 females) have been affected by the event, excluding those who were at the various health centers.

Reports from the National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) indicate that 500 buildings have been destroyed by the blasts and approximately 1,500 people are now homeless. The explosion blew-off major roads in the area, with many commuters getting stranded due to the situation. Schools, markets, and other services at the community level were equally impacted, disrupting activities as children can no longer go to school and community members have lost their livelihoods.

The Prestea Huni Valley Municipal Assembly has set up a relief center at the Catholic Church Parish Hall in Bogoso which is hosting the displaced people, and the Government through the Municipal Chief Executive of Prestea Huni Valley Municipal Assembly has issued a statement highlighting the need for assistance including temporary shelter, food items, and medical needs. The government is taking full charge of the medical bills of the injured while the Vice President of the Republic of Ghana, mining companies, and other non-profit organizations have provided cash (undisclosed amounts) and in-kind donations to the Municipal assembly, as a contribution to support relief actions.

A total of 17 people have unfortunately been confirmed dead, and 59 injured people have been rescued,” Information Minister Kojo Oppong Nkrumah said in a statement released overnight.
Seji Saji Amedonu, deputy director general of the National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO), said 500 buildings had been destroyed with 3300 people displaced. A regional emergency official told local media he had seen 17 dead bodies.
The explosion occurred when a motorcycle went under a truck carrying explosives that was on route to the Chirano gold mine, run by Canada-based Kinross.  A Kinross spokesperson confirmed the incident, saying it occurred 140km (87 miles) from the mine.
There were many unknown number of displaced people from their homes and took shelter in School, mosque, churches at Bogoso. The explosion blown off major road roads in the area, with many commuters getting stranded due to the situation. These also indicated immediate need for Water, food and NFIs including temporary shelter, beddings (blankets, mattresses and Cooking utensils).

The Ghana Health Authority confirmed  that two people who were suspected with Marburg cases later died and had been tested positive for the Marburg virus,. According to the health authorities the virus which causes a highly infectious disease is similar to Ebola. 

Preparations for a possible outbreak response are being set up swiftly as further investigations are underway. The two cases had no travel histories and had no contacts as the cases were from different districts.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The Ghana Health Service says 25 people have so far died from the recent outbreak of Yellow Fever in Savannah and Upper West Regions. The outbreak, which was initially detected in the Savannah Region, has now spread to the Wa East District of the Upper West Region, the statement added.

The GHS on the 29th October 2021 notified the public of an outbreak of Yellow Fever in some districts in the Savannah Region, with eight deaths reported. The outbreak was confirmed after initial laboratory test results were conducted by the Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research and the National Public Health Reference Laboratory. The GHS, subsequently, dispatched a team of experts from the service, World Health Organization Country Office, and the Centres for Disease Control (CDC) to the region to support the region investigate the outbreak and implement appropriate control measures.
field_reports.summary: Ghana Yellow  Fever outbreak: Deaths rise to 25  (17/11/2021)
field_reports.description:
The  affected regions health facilities  are resource challenged and with the outbreak of  yellow fever couple with COVID -19, the few  resources available  will be be over  stretched.
The affected communities are predominantly farming communities and the  affected population will be over burden with lost of breadwinners who otherwise provided for the up keep of the family. Psychosocial need is required for the bereaved family.

Yellow fever is an acute viral haemorrhagic disease transmitted by infected mosquitoes. The "yellow" in the name refers to the jaundice that affects some patients. Symptoms of yellow fever include fever, headache, jaundice, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting and fatigue. Yellow fever is prevented by an extremely effective vaccine, which is safe and affordable. People who are not vaccinated are encouraged to get vaccinated or wear long cloths to prevent mosquito bites especially those living and working around forested areas.

In the Upper West Region, the torrential rains between 12th and 13th August 2021 caused serious flooding and damaged to houses and farmlands leading to displacement of people and fatality. After assessment, it was declared emergency by the Government on 13th August 2021. The joint rapid assessment by National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) and Ghana Red Cross Society reported that a total of 2350 people were affected one way or the other in the Region, out of which 345 are children, 2 persons were reported dead across the region. Out of 1859 displaced people from their homes and 357 took shelter in Chiripon Basic School. A total of 85 communities from 6 districts were negatively affected by the floods. Over 335 houses were total destroyed with 256 others partially destroyed with occupants displaced and sheltered in nearby schools, and with relatives. The flood washed off major road roads in the area, farmlands, with many commuters getting stranded due to the situation. These also indicated immediate need for Water, food and NFIs including temporary shelter, beddings (blankets, mattresses & mats), kitchen sets, water collection and treatment tablets among others. Currently, the torrential rains continue and making it very difficult to access some of the affected communities in the region by road.
